Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project building on successes in NSF scholarship programs in biology and engineering at the university and is designed to support twenty-four students in chemistry and physics. The project is fills a need to improve the success rate of chemistry and physics students at the university and bridges a gap between biology and engineering. The project is adopting a multidisciplinary approach by recruiting chemistry and physics majors and placing them in a combined living learning community (LLC) that is housed in the same residence hall as the LLC Honors and Bio-Excellence students. The combined chemistry and physics LLC was chosen due to the large overlap in the disciplines and because these two disciplines are already utilizing an integrated approach that is facilitated through the coordination of the Offices of Undergraduate Studies for double majors in chemistry and physics. The overall goals of the project are increased retention in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM), shorter average time to graduation, and higher grade point averages (GPAs).

Intellectual Merit:
Despite the large number of students who explore STEM disciplines in their freshman year, high numbers of these students do not persist in STEM disciplines as they are either not prepared for the rigor or engaged in the courses. Early engagement of these students is essential to retain students in STEM disciplines. Further, academic success is significantly enhanced by financial aid and through social support from advisors and peers. Scholars are co-enrolled into the same sections of many classes to foster the community spirit of the LLC. The presence of these scholars is having a positive impact on the rest of their classmates. As the overall student confidence increases, class discussions are richer. Other students are more encouraged to ask questions in an environment they might otherwise find intimidating. The project is also collecting data to determine the effect of the LLC on GPA and retention in STEM majors.

Broader Impacts:
With the support of faculty, advisors and other campus support staff, this project is offering students who have solid academic preparation and the potential to succeed in STEM disciplines access access to higher education. The majority of these students are from groups that are underrepresented in STEM disciplines or are first generation students from an economically stressed region. The scholars are serving as messengers for science by disseminating their experiences as STEM majors, while also encouraging talented students to follow in their path. Additionally, the close interaction with other STEM scholars is providing the scholarship students with a unique perspective on the role of other STEM disciplines. Scholars are being given opportunities and encouragement to demonstrate a commitment to local and regional science activities, thereby instilling a sense of civic responsibility and awareness within them. This experience is providing the scholars with a strong foundation to help improve innovation and economic development on both a regional and national scale.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of the CAPS S-STEM program sponsored by the National Science Foundation were to recruit academically talented students strongly emphasizing recruitment in Eastern NC. This region is one of the most economically stressed regions in the US. In addition, particular emphasis would be placed on recruiting students from underrepresented minorities in STEM and also first-generation college students.

Once recruited these students would be placed in a discipline specific group in a residence hall to form a close cohort. In addition, they would interact closely with a small group of faculty in chemistry and physics to try to improve retention in STEM and at the University. This group of faculty would act as mentors to the students as well as providing academic advice. These students would also have specific programming organized for them throughout the academic year and they would be encouraged to engage in research and other academic and non-academic enriching activities.

A total of thirty-one students majoring in chemistry or physics received scholarship support through our program. Of these twenty-nine remained at the University and twenty-four of these students graduated with a STEM degree. Sixteen scholars are from underrepresented minority groups in STEM and fifteen were females and a 48% of them were first generation college students.

The four-year graduation rate for the scholars was 69%, almost twice the institutional rate of 35%.

The scholarship recipients were more likely to engage in research as undergraduates and 71% of them availed of this opportunity and resource, compared to 49% of a control group. We believe this is due to early engagement of the students coupled with intrusive mentoring and advising.

All of the freshmen scholars lived in the same residence hall and formed a Living Learning Community (LLC) of chemistry and physics scholars. This community still exists, and new freshmen are recruited into it yearly. Competition is high for a limited number of spaces, but we believe those who enroll in the LLC are more likely to seek help from advisors when they need it.

All of the scholars participated in a range of service events throughout the project and the LLC students are still heavily involved in these events, including volunteering at orientation, open house, recruitment events and academic enrichment events.

Of those scholars who have graduated at least thirteen have taken additional STEM courses (undergraduate and graduate) or they are currently working in a STEM field. In addition, three students are pursuing further education in medical, dental or pharmacy school.

In order to further encourage students, particularly those who are less likely, to participate in research the University has now initiated a larger scale project called TEAMS UR, where students can experience research in a required lab course. These research projects may be linked across many disciplines and they offer an easy path into research for many students.
